sentences: Bruce Clinton Haack listen  (May 4, 1931 – September 26, 1988) was a Canadian musician and composer in the field of electronic music.
From Alberta to New York (1931-1963)
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: While the band played primarily modern and old-time music, they also performed Ukrainian Folk music, which introduced Haack to Eastern musical motifs and themes.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: In later years, Haack's painting of St. Basil is said to be reminiscent of his earlier years with The Swing Tones in Edmonton.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: In later years, Haack's painting of St. Basil is said to be reminiscent of his earlier years with The Swing Tones in Edmonton.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: Haack was also invited by Aboriginal peoples in Canada to participate in their pow-wows, experimenting with peyote, which influenced his music for years to come.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: New York City's Juilliard School offered Haack the opportunity to study with composer Vincent Persichetti; thanks to a scholarship from the Canadian government, he headed to New York upon graduating from Edmonton in 1954.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: However, his studies proved less sympathetic, and he dropped out of Juilliard just eight months later, rejecting the school's restrictive approach.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: He spent the rest of the 1950s scoring dance and theater productions, as well as writing pop songs for record labels like Dot Records and Coral Records.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: Haack's early scores, like 1955's Les Etapes, suggested the futuristic themes and experimental techniques Haack developed in his later works.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: Originally commissioned for a Belgian ballet, Les Etapes mixed tape samples, electronics, soprano, and violin; the following year, he finished a musique concrète piece called "Lullaby for a Cat".
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: As the 1960s began, the public's interest in electronic music and synthesizers increased, and so did Haack's notoriety.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: Along with songwriting and scoring, Haack appeared on TV shows like I've Got a Secret and The Tonight Show starring Johnny Carson, usually with Pandel in tow.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: The duo often played the Dermatron, a touch- and heat-sensitive synthesizer, on the foreheads of guests; 1966's appearance on I've Got a Secret featured them playing 12 "chromatically pitched" young women.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: Meanwhile, Haack wrote serious compositions as well, such as 1962's "Mass for Solo Piano", which Pandel performed at Carnegie Hall, and a song for Rocky Mountain House's 50th anniversary.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: One of his most futuristic pieces, 1963's "Garden of Delights", mixed Gregorian chants and electronic music.
section: == Biography == | === From Alberta to New York (1931-1963) ===

sentences: As the 1960s progressed and the musical climate became more receptive to his kind of whimsical innovation, Haack's friend, collaborator, and business manager Chris Kachulis found mainstream applications for his music.
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: He also continued to promote electronic music on television, demonstrating his homemade device encased in a suitcase on Mister Rogers' Neighborhood in 1968, where he sampled a song by the Rolling Stones entitled "Citadel".
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: He released The Way-Out Record for Children later that year.
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: Acid rock's expansive nature was a perfect match for Haack's style, and in 1969 he released his first rock-influenced work, The Electric Lucifer.
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: As the 1970s started, Haack's musical horizons continued to expand.
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: After the release of The Electric Lucifer, he continued on Lucifer's rock-influenced musical approach with 1971's Together, an electronic pop album that marked his return to Dimension 5.
section: == Biography == | ==== From Children's Music to Electric Lucifer (1963-1976) ====

sentences: Haack continued making children's albums as well, including 1972's Dance to the Music, 1974's Captain Entropy, and 1975's This Old Man, which featured science fiction versions of nursery rhymes and traditional songs.

sentences: It seems to have inspired Haack's final landmark work, 1981's Bite.
section: == Biography == | === From Party Machine to Death (1977-1988) ===

sentences: Haack's failing health slowed Dimension 5's musical output in the early 1980s, but Nelson and Pandel kept the label alive by publishing songbooks, like Fun to Sing and The World's Best Funny Songs, and re-released selected older albums as cassettes which are still available today.
section: == Biography == | === From Party Machine to Death (1977-1988) ===

sentences: Haack's failing health slowed Dimension 5's musical output in the early 1980s, but Nelson and Pandel kept the label alive by publishing songbooks, like Fun to Sing and The World's Best Funny Songs, and re-released selected older albums as cassettes which are still available today.
section: == Biography == | === From Party Machine to Death (1977-1988) ===

sentences: In 1982, Haack recorded his swan song, a proto hip-hop collaboration with Def Jam's Russell Simmons, entitled "Party Machine".
section: == Biography == | === From Party Machine to Death (1977-1988) ===

sentences: Haack died in 1988 from heart failure, but his label and commitment to making creative children's music survives.
